questions.text: As per FAB classification, what percentage of blast cells in bone marrow biopsy is required to diagnose a patient with acute leukaemia?
questions.explanation:
WHO classification

FAB (French-American-British) classification

Basis of classification

It incorporates genetics, immunophenotypic, and morphological features.

It is primarily based on morphology and cytochemistry

Subtypes
  • B-cell ALL, NOS (not otherwise specified).
  • B-cell ALL with recurrent genetic abnormalities.
  • T-cell ALL.
  • ALL-L1- small uniform cells
  • ALL-L2- large cells with irregular nuclei
  • ALL-L3- large cells with regular nuclei

Prognostic information

It provides prognostic information based on genetic abnormalities.

Limited prognostic information and focused on morphology.

Clinical utility

Used for diagnosis, treatment, and prognostication.

Less commonly used in clinical practice and more historical.

Diagnosis threshold

>20% blasts in the bone marrow.

>30% blasts in the bone marrow.

questions.text: Which is not included in the FAB classification of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) L3 subtype?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of lymphoblasts with vacuoles and cytoplasmic blebs

questions.explanation:
L1

L2

L3

Occurrence

More common

-

Less common

Morphology

Small homogenous blasts

Large heterogenous blasts

Large homogenous blasts

Cytoplasm

Scant blue

Moderately weak basophilic

Abundant basophilic with prominent vacuoles

Nucleus

Regular

Irregular nuclear outlines

-

Nucleoli

Small & indistinct

Prominent

-

Chromatin

Coarse & dark purple

Pink

-

Prognosis

Best

-

Poor

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) regarding chromosomes?

A 4-year-old male presents with fever, bleeding gums, and fatigue for 5 days. CBC shows Hb of 8g%, TLC 30,000/µL, and platelet count of 40,000/µL. A differential count shows an increased number of immature white blood cells. A bone marrow aspiration is done, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Symptoms

  • Due to decline in normal marrow function.
  • Fatigue - anaemia.
  • Infections - neutropenia.
  • Bleeding - thrombocytopenia

Mass effects

  • Bone pain due to marrow expansion and infiltration of the subperiosteum.
  • Generalised lymphadenopathy.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Testicular enlargement.
  • Mediastinal mass in T-ALL (Superior mediastinal syndrome).

CNS manifestations
  • Headache.
  • Vomiting.
  • Nerve palsies.

questions.text: Which of the following markers will be negative on immunophenotyping of a patient with early pre-B acute leukaemia?
questions.explanation:
Type of ALL

Immunophenotype

Early Pre-B ALL

TdT, DR, CD19, CD24 

Pre-B ALL

TdT, DR, CD10, CD19, CD20, CD24, Cy Ig

Common ALL

CD19+, CD10+/CALLA+

Mature B ALL

DR, CD19 CD20, CD24, Surface Ig

Pro-T ALL

CD3, CD7 

Pre-T ALL

TdT, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8, CD34

Mature T ALL

CD2, CD7, TdT

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the prognosis of ALL? Adults have a worse prognosis as compared to children aged 2-9 years. White females have a good survival rate as compared to black males. The Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)) is associated with a favourable prognosis. Higher white blood cell counts at diagnosis are associated with a better prognosis. Hypodiploidy in B-ALL is associated with a better prognosis.
questions.explanation:
Determinants

Favourable

Unfavourable

WBC/µL

<10,000

>1,00,000 (Statement D)

Age

2-9 years

<1 year, >10 years (Statement A)

Gender

Female

Male

Ethnicity

White (Statement B)

Black

Lymph node, liver, spleen enlargement

Absent

Present

Testicular enlargement

Absent

Present

CNS involvement

Absent

Present

FAB morphologic features

L1, early pre-B cell ALL

L3, Pre-B cell & mature B-cell ALL

Ploidy

Hyperdiploidy

Hypodiploidy (Statement E)

Cytogenetic markers

Trisomy 4, 10, 17, t(12;21)

t(9;22), t(4;11) (Statement C)

Remission states

<14 days

>14 days

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with fever, fatigue, and bone pain. On physical examination, there is notable hepatosplenomegaly and testicular enlargement. Laboratory findings show elevated white blood cell count and blasts on peripheral smear. Immunophenotyping reveals the presence of markers CD3, CD5, and CD10. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. T cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
questions.explanation:
ALL
 

AML

(Option A)

CML

(Option D)
 

B cell -ALL

(Option C)

T cell -ALL

(Option B)

    
 

Most common

Less common (15%)

M2 (M/C)

-

Children

Teenagers

Middle-Elderly

Mutation

Loss of function PAX5, E2A, EBF

Gain of function NOTCH1

t(15:17) in M3,
t (8:21) in M2

t(9:22) BCR-ABL fusion gene. 

Prognosis

Good

Poor

Good 

Good

Massive splenomegaly, hepatomegaly

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the M4 subtype of AML based on FAB classification is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is associated with t(8:21), called AML with maturation.

options.label: B
options.text: It is associated with t(15:17), called acute promyelocytic leukaemia

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with CBF-MYH fusion, called acute myelomonocytic leukaemia

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with MPO positivity, called AML without maturation.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is associated with CBF-MYH fusion, called acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
questions.explanation:
FAB classification of AML

Subtype

Name

Features

AML-M0

AML undifferentiated
  • MPO negative

AML-M1

AML without maturation (Option D)
  • MPO +

AML-M2

AML with maturation
(Option A)
  • Most common
  • t(8:21) RUNX1-RUNX1T1 fusion
  • Associated with chloroma.

AML-M3

Acute promyelocytic leukaemia
(Option B)
  • t(15:17) - PML-RAR𝛼 fusion
  • Blocks promyelocyte → myelocyte transformation
  • Bone marrow: Auer rods form criss-cross called faggot cell

  • Can cause DIC
  • PAS+

AML-M4

Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
(Option C)
  • Associated with inv 16 and CBF-MYH fusion gene
  • Gums - gum hypertrophy
  • Skin - leukaemia cutis
  • MPO+, NSE +

AML-M5

Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Gums - gum hypertrophy
  • Skin - leukaemia cutis
  • MPO-, NSE +

AML-M6

Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Also called DI Guglielmo Disease
  • Diffuse PAS+, CD71

AML-M7

Acute megakaryocytic leukaemia
  • Bone Marrow aspiration gives a dry tap
  • PAS+, CD41 and CD61

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with fatigue, bruising, and intermittent fevers for the past few weeks. Physical examination reveals the following findings. Immunophenotyping of the biopsy specimen shows CD43 and MPO positivity. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old female was admitted to the hospital with complaints of frequent nosebleeds, reports of sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea. On examination, she has petechiae and ecchymoses on her skin. Laboratory tests revealed WBC 15,000/µL, haemoglobin 8 g/dL, platelets 20,000/µL and elevated prothrombin time. A peripheral blood smear shows the following findings. Further testing confirms which of the following associated conditions?
Which of the following types of AML, according to the FAB classification, is associated with Down’s syndrome?
Which of the following is associated with a good prognosis according to WHO classification of AML?
questions.correct_answer: C. AML with recurrent genetic abnormality

questions.text: What is the most likely immunophenotype associated with the condition indicated by the peripheral blood smear shown below?

A 55-year-old female presented with fatigue, easy bruising, and recurrent infections over the past few months. On examination, there is mild splenomegaly, but no lymphadenopathy is noted. Laboratory tests reveal pancytopenia. A peripheral blood smear shows normocytic normochromic red blood cells and no blast cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
